data.text: Contents
Purpose
To determine whether the newborn infant has made a successful transition from fetal life.
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix L)
Aim

The newborn physical examination is a holistic assessment of the health and well- being of the newborn baby. The baby is examined from top to toe by a qualified healthcare professional, including a screening examination of the heart, hips, eyes and testes in boys.
To ascertain baseline recordings.
To impart advice and reassurance to parents.
Overview

At booking all women are provided with written information, in the form of the booklet entitled ‘Screening tests for you and your baby' or in a format appropriate to their individual requirements. Parents should be offered information antenatally at approximately  weeks, in written form as well as verbally and should be repeated prior to the newborn examination being offered.
The following neonatal examinations should be undertaken:
The initial examination;
The routine baby examination;
The formal examination.

The initial examination should be carried out by the midwife, a paediatrician or advanced neonatal nurse practitioner in the presence of the parents, in a warm environment with good light. This initial examination should be undertaken as soon as possible after birth.

A formal examination of the newborn should be carried out during the first 72 hours. This must be carried out by a competent practitioner – usually a paediatric senior house officer, an advanced neonatal nurse practitioner (ANNP), or  midwife  who has undertaken the course entitled ‘Newborn and Infant Physical Examination' (NIPE).
At each postnatal contact, a routine baby examination should be performed with parental consent and documented in the patient's health care records

The formal examination will also include four Screening Standard examinations on the eyes, heart, hips and testes. All babies should undergo the routine screening procedures but if risk factors are present or when a possible problem is detected, further tests may be indicated. This formal examination excludes hearing test as this is done separately by Audiology staff as part of postnatal checks. If there are no problems, this examination need not be repeated before discharge.
For babies being discharged from hospital at 6 hours the formal examination should be carried out as near to 6 hours as possible, avoiding times between midnight and 0600 hours.
Initial examination
Wash your hands and ensure the appropriate PPE is applied/worn.
Introduce yourself and seek full consent of the mother (or both parents if present) before examining the baby.
Professional Consent for purposes of adoption or no parental responsibility.
If parental consent is declined, this must be entered onto NIPESmart and examined cannot be performed.
Other reasons for the examination not proceeding must be entered on NIPESmart within 72 hour i.e. medically unstable or transfer to another unit.
For full consent explain the purpose of the examination and undertake the following:
Observe the infants colour, tone, posture and activity
Examine the skin and the clamped cord for signs of bleeding

Examine the infant thoroughly for any abnormalities working from head to toe, ( if forceps/ instruments used during birth ensure examination of the head for any signs of trauma prior to applying a hat).
Inspection of the hard and soft palate is not considered an aerosol generating
procedure (AGP).
Measure head circumference
Take the ‘axillary' temperature with a digital thermometer
Weigh the baby (in grams) on the scales, lined with a paper towel, ask the
mother /partner to check the weight registered.
Administer Konakion (vitamin K) according with parental choice and with their consent (Refer to ‘Guideline for the administration of vitamin K'. Register number 08095)
Check the infant's two identification labels with the mother's label, ensuring that the details have been checked with the parents before attaching them around the baby's ankles.
Dress the baby in warm clothes and a hat
Note passage of urine and/or meconium
Record all the findings in maternity health care records/computer and baby's details on a cot label.
Routine baby examination
Wash your hands and ensure the appropriate PPE is applied/worn.
Undertake the following assessment:
Begin the examination by observing the infants general appearance and behaviour.
Activity State, sleeping/awake, spontaneous symmetrical movements, tremors/twitching/seizures and muscle tone
Colour, central/peripheral cyanosis jaundice, excessive bruising and pink/pale/plethoric/mottled.
Posture and symmetry appropriate for gestational age
Cry, note character of cry
Feeding – method and frequency
Elimination of urine and meconium
Observations – heart rate, respirations and temperature.
Formal examination ‘newborn and infant physical examination' (NIPE)
Examination can be carried out at any point between birth and 72 hours, by an appropriate trained health care professional

Gain verbal consent from parents for examination to be performed, The examiner needs to provide the relevant information to parents before the examination together with an opportunity to discuss the forthcoming screens, eyes, heart, hips and testes Wash your hands and ensure the appropriate PPE is
applied/worn..
Screening declined  Screening accepted
Review of maternal pregnancy / delivery notes for significant history
Family history
Maternal medical problems
Booking blood results
Fetal scan results
Antenatal details
Risk factors for infection
Presentation at 36 weeks gestation & beyond.
Details of labour
Social history
Resuscitation details / Apgar's
Birth weight
Condition of baby since birth (i.e. feeding, passed urine / meconium)
Family history of congenital deafness and congenital dislocation of the hip, heart conditions or any hereditary conditions
Examination  Examination  Examination  Examination of the Heart  of the Hips  of the Eyes  of the
Testes
Complete full examination of the baby – see below text for details Inform parents of examination findings and a plan of care
Screen negative – all  Screen positive – need for
well, no concerns  referral

Examination  Examination  Examination Routine  Any other  Examination  of the Hips –  of the Eyes  of the care and  concerns on  of the Heart –  development – eye  Testes – infant  examination  congenital  al dysplasia  conditions  undescende physical  heart defects  of the hips  including  d testes
examinatio cataracts
n at 6-8
weeks
Refer as appropriate – see Referral
In order to provide a duty of care, the examination must be carried out by an appropriate trained health professional –

Newborn examination – a doctor (paediatrician or GP) who is competent to undertake all elements  of  the  newborn  examination  or  a  midwife,  nurse  or  health  visitor  who  has successfully undertaken an accredited ‘examination of the newborn programme of study.
Infant examination (NIPE) – a doctor (paediatrician or GP) or Midwife who is competent to undertake all elements of the NIPE examination.

Screening Failsafe Officer – is responsible for reviewing NIPE SMART system and highlighting any babies who have not had a NIPE check who are flagging as amber on the database; to either the NIPE midwife rostered that day or the ward / birth centre where the baby is receiving care.
The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies,
guidelines and SOPs are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines  and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the  directorate.
The Head of Nursing and Quality for Children and Young People, the Head of
Midwifery, the managers of both neonatal and postnatal wards are responsible for ensuring that all relevant staff are aware of the guideline and
implement it.
The Paediatric Clinical Lead Consultant is responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All paediatric staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Where there is no midwife cover for the NIPE checks on the maternity unit, paediatricians are expected to perform all examinations that are required.
Where there is a midwife and paediatrician available to perform NIPE checks; babies should  be  allocated  to  appropriate  practitioner  based  on  risk  factors  to undertake the examination.
NIPE Smart system needs to access to identify any babies requiring an examination. A To Do  list  may  be  printed from  NIPE  smart  and  added  to postnatal  ward  diaries  as  per appendix A.
Babies examined by midwives trained in newborn examination must fall within the
following criteria:
Birth weight 2.5kg or more, gestation  weeks and above
Apgar >7 at 5 minutes and arterial cord Ph >7.1
Spontaneous vaginal delivery with no causes for concern
Instrumental deliveries with birth trauma not requiring analgesia or paediatric assessment prior to NIPE
Elective “low risk” Caesarean sections with no family history of co-morbidities.
Emergency Caesarean sections where the Apgar was > 7 at 5 minutes and arterial cord pH> 7.1

Non- significant and significantly stained liquor, where Apgar score was > 7 at 5 minutes, arterial pH > 7.1 and following satisfactorily completed observations, with no signs of sepsis. If no cord PH's available and baby is born in good condition with apgars greater than 7 at five minutes; all observations are completed and fall within normal parameters then NIPE trained midwives are able to undertake the examination.(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Postnatal observations of babies born with prolonged rupture of membranes and meconium stained liquor'; register number 08074)

Prolonged rupture of membranes (>24 hours in a term baby) following satisfactorily completed observations, with no signs of sepsis (Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Postnatal observations of babies born with prolonged rupture of membranes and meconium stained liquor'; register number 08074)

Breech deliveries, both vaginal and Caesarean, where appropriate referral is made for hip scan (Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Identification and Referral of Infants with Developmental Dysplasia of the Hips (DDH); register number 10085) and (Calling Paediatric Staff and obtaining Paediatric Referral; register number 09113).

Gestational diabetic mothers, diet controlled, when babies are stable following satisfactory observations (Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Treatment of neonatal hypoglycaemia in the high risk infant'; register number 12025)

Mothers on an only single low dose drug SSRI who's baby requires 48 hours of neonatal abstinence syndrome observations, when baby's observations are satisfactory with no cause for concern. Neonatal Alerts must always accessed and instructions followed (Refer to guideline ‘Treatment of Infants suffering from Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome' Register number 09029)
The following babies must be referred to a paediatrician or ANNP for examination as they may require treatment or follow up:
Birth weight under 2.5kg (2nd centile WHO Growth Chart) and gestation <37 weeks - Preterm

Significant / Non- significant MSL babies should be reviewed by a paediatrician if the baby's condition causes concern at any time (Refer to ‘Guideline for the management of MSL'. Register number 04259)
Abnormalities detected in the antenatal period i.e. dilated renal pelvis
Babies who at birth required intubation and advanced resuscitation or assessed at delivery with a problem
Cord arterial pH < 7.1
Apgar below 7 at 5 minutes
Birth trauma requiring analgesia or cause for concern
Any congenital abnormality including congenital heart disease and family history of any genetic or inherited disorder
Women with Insulin dependent diabetes
Blood disorders i.e. high antibody titres
Known maternal infection i.e. Herpes, GBS, Hepatitis B or C, HIV
Suspected or declared maternal alcohol and drug misuse requiring neonatal abstinence syndrome observations

Mothers on an only single low dose drug SSRI who's baby requires 48 hours of neonatal abstinence syndrome observations, when baby's observations are unsatisfactory with cause for concern. Neonatal Alerts must always be accessed and instructions followed (Refer to guideline ‘Treatment of Infants suffering from Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome' Register number 09029)

Mothers on prescribed single or multiple drugs who's baby requires 72 hours of neonatal abstinence syndrome observations. Neonatal Alerts must always be accessed and instructions followed (Refer to guideline ‘Treatment of Infants suffering from Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome' Register number 09029)
Admitted to neonatal intensive care unit
History of Oligohydramnios / Polyhydramnios
Prolonged rupture of membranes with offensive liquor and observations that cause concern

The infant's general condition must be assessed prior to the examination to ensure he/she is able to tolerate the procedure. If there is any concern regarding the baby's condition, the examination should be abandoned and the paediatrician informed.

table_items.text: sleeping/awake, spontaneous symmetrical movements, tremors / twitching / seizures, muscle tone

central/peripheral cyanosis jaundice, excessive bruising pink / pale / plethoric / mottled. These changes maybe seen in darker skin infants inside their mouth (mucus membranes), the whites of their eyes, soles of their feet or the palms of their hands. Additionally during a capillary refill.
rate, characteristics. e.g. nasal flaring, recession, laboured, equal movement.
plot on centile chart – ensure appropriate for gestational age Head circumference: plot on centile chart – ensure appropriate for gestational age
3 seconds or less is normal. Absent or delayed capillary refill is abnormal
rate, rhythm and regularity, evidence of murmurs (loudness, quality, location and timing) sound 1 & 2, Apex beat position and character
air entry, bronchial breath sounds, hyper or decreased resonance, expiratory grunt.
palpate for organs/masses (hepatomegaly) and observe appearance, e.g.: scaphoid or distended
Examine the umbilical cord. Ensure it is well clamped. Ensure that three vessels are present. Note any protrusions at the base of the cord as this may indicate a hernia.
bulging/sunken, presence of a third fontanelle
noting presence of vernix, injury, meconium staining, rashes, lanugo, texture, birthmarks, oedema, colour and bruising . Body Map if significant.

co-ordinated movements, red reflexes, presence of sub or Scleral haemorrhage, size, shape, structure and reaction of pupils, abdominal discharge, epicanthic folds, brushfield spots, cataracts, position.
cartilage development, size, shape, position and angle, response to noise, skin tags/sinus.
shape and size, patency, abnormal discharge

colour of lips and membranes, anomalies of hard/soft palate (refer to RCPCH 2014), presence of neonatal teeth, size/shape of tongue-tie, excessive saliva, evidence of infection. Inspection of the soft palate is not considered an aerosol generating procedure (AGP).
present of abdominal defects, observe and palpate cord
male – urethral opening, testes, hydrocele female – urethral opening, position of clitoris, skin tags, fistulas
flat and straight vertebral column, observe coccygeal area, note and abnormal pigmentation/hairy patches
size, shape, symmetry of arms and hands, signs of fractures, paralysis and dislocations count and inspect digits note range of movements, simian creases present
size, shape, symmetry of legs and feet, note normal position of flexion and abduction/range of movements observe for fractures, dislocation and paralysis, count and inspect digits.
note method of feeding, nutritional status of the infant
note meconium plug/delay in passing meconium
Demonstrate presence of the following reflexes
Sucking, swallowing, (gag reflex only if concerned) Grasp reflex, step reflex, moro reflex

data.text: (Refer to Appendix A)

Appointments are booked via the postnatal ward where the NIPE clinic diary is situated. These are for infants whom require a Paediatric NIPE but born in other settings i.e. home or birthing centres (WJC St Michael Hospital, Braintree or St Peters Maternity, Maldon) or if there is no NIPE trained midwife available to perform within the home or birthing centre. It is the responsibility of the booking practitioner to ensure the appropriate NIPE practitioner is appointed; while ensuring that the NIPE check is completed within the 72 hour window.

If the baby will fall out of the window for examination for any reason – the discharging midwife should discuss with the bleep holder / manager to make arrangements for the NIPE check to be completed within the timeframe – possibility that other staff could perform check.
For babies born at WJC or St Peters the NIPE check can be completed by an appropriate practitioner at the birth centre or can be referred to the NIPE outpatient appointment for review.
All infants require their NIPE examination before discharge to the community setting. (See  Appendix A and B)

The practitioner responsible for the Midwife NIPE shift, should contact any women that do not attend. They must determine the reason for not attending and document in the diary and offer another appointment as soon as possible and within 72 hours of birth.
It may be possible to offer an appointment at another facility – WJC / St Peters / Broomfield Hospital.
If the examination is carried out later than the 72 hours from delivery then a datix must be completed; stating reason why there was a delay.

If the woman declines to attend for the NIPE check, please inform the screening office if the examination is not carried out. The woman must be advised to contact their GP for the screening to be completed as soon as possible and again at 6-8 weeks.

The clinician examining the baby must have the knowledge and ability to refer promptly and directly to the appropriate specialist clinician, when an actual and / or potential problem is identified (Appendix F)
Congenital Heart Defects (Screening Standard) :

13.2.1 All babies, who are screen positive should have pre and post ductal pulse oximetry and 4 limb blood pressures prior to an expert examination within 24 hours of the initial examination. Following this examination the need for further tests and/or an outpatient appointment should be assessed depending on the clinical condition and any significant risk of clinical deterioration.

All babies with a hip abnormality should be referred and discussed with a senior paediatric clinican for a plan of action. Babies who are found to have a dislocated or dislocatable hip, positive Ortolani or Barlow manoeuvre should be urgently referred to a orthopaedic consultant and Helen Gille orthopaedic nurse specialist See Appendix C,D & F) for an urgent hip ultrasound as soon as identified; with the ultrasound being performed within two weeks of birth (refer to guideline ‘Infants with Developmental Dysplasia of the Hips' register number 10085) .
Examination of the Eye (Screening Standard)
13.4.1 All babies who have an eye abnormality detected on initial examination should be further reviewed by a paediatric registrar/consultant and an immediate ophthalmology referral as urgent.
13.4.2 If they require treatment they must be seen be an ophthalmology consultant before two weeks of age.
Undescended testes (Screening Standard):
13.5.1 Only babies with bilateral undescended testes to be seen by a senior paediatrician within 24hours.
13.5.2 If Bilateral undescended testes are confirmed. Paediatric consultant to formulate investigation, management and follow up plan before baby is discharged from hospital.

Babies in neonatal unit should be assessed and if well enough the NIPE screen should be undertaken within 72 hours of age. It is acknowledged that some babies are too ill at the time the examination is due and the NIPE screen is not always appropriate.

Where possible babies should have screening as soon as practicable. Some elements of the examination may need to be repeated in very preterm babies but referrals should still be made regarding positive cases.
Referral timescales should not be age adjusted for preterm babies.
Babies less than 32 weeks gestation or less than 1500gms birth weight should be screened for retinopathy of prematurity.

On completion of the formal newborn examination, the trained healthcare professional should communicate all findings to the mother; including any concerns for referral to the paediatric team. Any discussions/ care should documented accordingly in the ‘Postnatal Care Record – Baby'
If there are no problems, complete the discharge examination section of the baby's health record (postnatal, neonatal and PCHR records)

Ensure that the outcome of the examination is appropriately recorded on NIPE SMART system. If access cannot be gained to the NIPE SMART database ensure that all documentation is clearly written with Infants Name and NHS number and the examination is signed by the practitioner and name is printed and left with the Screening Office to ensure timely documentation on the system of examination;

If a problem has been identified by the paediatric SHO/registrar or ANNP, dependent on the clinical indications, they may initiate the management plan and any further investigations/treatments as indicated. Where indicated, they should refer to the registrar

In house management plans and follow up arrangements for ophthalmology, plastic surgery, dermatology for example and for other hospitals or GP's should be documented in the baby's healthcare records. A referral letter composed on Lorenzo to appropriate medical department and an email request to be sent to the Paediatric secretaries for forwarding of the referral letter (Appendix F).

For follow up with one of the Paediatric consultants what is needed is to follow the procedure outlined in “Calling paediatric staff and obtaining paediatric referral” guidelines, register number 09113, by completing the form in appendix B. Documenting that clearly on the NIPESmart report. Ward Clerk or Paediatric Secretaries to upload this referral to Lorenzo as a clinical note.
The GP, community midwife and Health Visitor should be informed of any referrals. The GP / Health Visitor should receive copies of referral letters.
A  further  6-8  week  physical  examination  is  conducted  by  the  GP.  The  examination completes a second systematic head to toe physical examination of the infant.
See Appendix E for processes; this is mainly carrier out by the Failsafe Officer, but can be carried out by any professional with NIPE SMART access within the unit.

If IT failure occurs the screening should be hand written and recorded on page 22 of the Postnatal Care Record – Baby book and then photocopied and left in the NIPE examination book / room on postnatal ward, to be uploaded onto NIPE SMART when the system is working..

For babies with screen positive results for eyes, heart, testes, babies should reviewed by Registrar/consultant and management & follow up plans discussed with the consultant before discharge. For positive hip scans babies should be referred as per Positive screen section (Appendix C & D).
Failsafe Officer Tracking for Positive Hip scans –
RUN SEARCH FOR HIP REFERRAL AWAITING OUTCOME IN NIPE SMART ON A WEEKLY BASIS
REVIEW NIPE SCREENING FOR OUTCOMES AND REFERRAL STATUS FOR ALL BABIES FOUND IN REPORT ADD TO SPREADSHEET
REVIEW LORENZO FOR HIP SCAN DETAILS AND CALCULATE TIME FROM DATE OF BIRTH TO SCAN DATE
WITHIN 2 WEEKS  NOT WITHIN 2 WEEKS
NO FURTHER ACTION  SONOGRAPHER MADE AWARE TO CHANGE APPOINTMENT IF
POSSIBLE AND FEEDBACK TO FAILSAFE OFFICER
(Refer to ‘Mandatory training policy for Maternity Services (incorporating training needs analysis. Register number 09062)

It is the individual practitioners responsibility to ensure that keep their clinical skills up to date, with a minimum of 12 NIPE checks completed each year. Evidence can be obtained from the NIPE SMART system – please speak to the Screening Coordinator or Screening Failsafe Officer to access this information.

For all practioners undertaking the NIPE examination an annual update is requires by all individuals, this may include practical and theoretical assessment and annual completion of the NIPE e-Learning Module (registration and password are required to access the resource – this can be done by the individual) https://www.e-lfh.org.uk/
Newly qualified midwives who are considered competent in their NIPE examination will have NIPE experience built into their perceptorship programme.

All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes examination of the newborn infant at birth and daily checks; this is undertaken as part of the yearly mandatory training sessions.
Guideline Management

19.5.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Incident to be reported by individuals identifying the incident on Datix, this will be followed up by review by the Clinical Risk Manager / Maternity Management team and the Screening Coordinator.

Screening Incident Assessment Form (SIAF) to be completed by the Screening Coordinator / Clinical Governance Manager and submitted to PHE and the PHE's Screening Quality Assurance (QA) Team within 5 days of the incident being reported.
A report of all actions/recommendation arising from the incident will be pulled from DATIX and reviewed at ANNB steering group meeting.
See “Managing safety incidents in NHS screening programmes”
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/managing-safety-incidents-in-nhs-screening- programmes for more information and guidance on the process for investigating screening programme
incidents.
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention.

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy and the Maternity annual audit work plan. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The audit findings will be reported to and approved at the Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group Report will be reported to the monthly
Directorate Governance Meeting on a quarterly basis and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Quality and Safety Committee (PSQC) within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Regular memos are posted on the guideline notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.
Anglia Ruskin University (2009) Examination of Newborn Course E-Learning for Healthcare (2020) https://www.e-lfh.org.uk/
National institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (2006) Routine postnatal care of women and their babies. London: NICE www.nice.org.uk
National Health Service (2018) Symptoms: Newborn jaundice. https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/jaundice-newborn/symptoms/0512
National institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (2007) Intrapartum Care: Care of healthy women and their babies during childbirth. London: NICE www.nice.org.uk
NHS Quality Improvement Scotland (2008) Best Practice Statement - May 2008. Routine Examination of the Newborn. Edinburgh: NHS Quality Improvement Scotland www.nhshealthyquality.org
NMC (2004) PREPP Standard. NMC London.
Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (2013) UK WHO Growth Charts 0-4 years. https://www.rcpch.ac.uk/resources/uk-who-growth-charts-0-4-years
Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (2014) Palate examination:
Identification of cleft palate in the newborn https://www.rcpch.ac.uk/sites/default/files/2018- 04/2015_palate_examination_-_best_practice_guide.pdf
Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (2020) COVID-19 guidence for neonatal setting. https://www.rcpch.ac.uk/resources/covid-19-guidance-neonatal-settings
UK National Screening Committee (2008) Newborn and Infant Physical Examination : Standards and Competencies
Appendix A: Role and Responsibilities of Newborn and Infant Physical Examination Midwife on Shift 08.30-16.30
Check triage room/ clinical room / equipment is clean and ready for use
Access NIPESmart. Print a To-do List. Locate infants on Lorenzo or ward handover sheet i.e. labour ward, birthing unit or postnatal ward.
Allocate NIPE to appropriate practitioner (Paediatrician or Midwife) as per guideline and enter into Postnatal Ward diaries. Telephone off site locations to confirm intent to get NIPE completed.
Check infant triage appointments. Facilitate these autonomously or alongside the Paediatric team.

Organise own work load and liaise with the Midwife in Charge of Postnatal/Bleep holder regarding the needs of the unit for discharges. Prioritise infants flagged as Amber nearing the  hour cut off or any infants flagged as RED on NIPE Smart

Perform NIPEs as per guideline. Work alongside and support Paediatrician allocated to NIPE shift. Washing hands before and after each examination. Wearing appropriate PPE. Mask need not be changed, however new gloves and aprons are required for each examination.
Organise own suitable time for lunch break.
Approx 2pm re-check NIPESmart. Re-allocate any infants over 6 hours of age to the Postnatal Ward Diaries. Inform the Paediatrician of further examinations.
If no further NIPE's offer lunch cover or clinical assistance to Postnatal Ward

Enter data as soon as possible on NIPE Smart, completing any referrals. Please input escalation process in the free text area of the report >Action taken i.e. Oxygen saturations and 4 limb blood pressures. >Document whom accepted the referral i.e. Dr Jane Smith and if any outpatient appointments have been made. Print the NIPE report. Secure 1 copy onto page 22 of the Baby -postnatal book and 1 copy on page 3 of the red Medical Health Record Books.

Failsafe Procedure. If the system is down then record in the Baby-Postnatal Book (NIPE  template page 22) and page 3 of the red Child Health Record Book. NIPE template then  needs to be photocopied and a copy put in the folder of the clinical room on Postnatal Ward or under the screening office door for entry on NIPE system when it can be accessed again. Please ensure the baby's Name & NHS number is added to the copy alongside a clear name of practitioner.

Should there be an urgent referral for heart, eyes, hip or other concerns immediate contact  with paediatric registrar should be made and a plan in place before the patient goes home. NIPESmart requires updating.
Hip scans requests, BCG or tongue tie referrals to be made prior to discharge & documented.
Any unfinished NIPES should be passed on to the Paediatric SHO for completion or for review the following day as long as completed within the  hour as per standards.
NIPE should be completed before discharge to the Community Setting. However low risk infants can be transferred to WJC and St Peters ensuring that they have a NIPE qualified practitioner available.
Write any outstanding jobs or messages in the NIPE diary for following day.
Ensure room and equipment is left clean and tidy
Capacity Escalation - Exceptional circumstances for NIPE examinations to aid mobility and discharges in Maternity

Senior Midwife or Midwife in charge of PN Ward for the Night Shift to identify 4 babies at the beginning of the shift that maybe suitable for Paediatric NIPE and discharge by 08:00hrs. With the hope that 2 will be fit for discharge by 08:00hrs (the mothers must happy to be discharged and partners informed to collect their families).
Inform the Paediatrician at the beginning of the night shift that their presence will be required to perform 2 NIPE's between 06:00-08:00hrs.
There will not be an expectation do to any more than 2 during the night shift.

In exceptional circumstances where hospital capacity threatens closure of the maternity unit please inform the Paediatrician at the beginning of the shift to enable the Night shift Paediatrician to appropriately plan their work load.
The night shift Paediatric SHO is not expected to do routine work i.e. NIPE out of hours (RCPCH). Emergencies in other areas will always take priority.
Appendix B: Infants requiring NIPE and allocation to appropriate practitioner – Print To-Do List
Appendix C: Indications for Hip Referrals
Appendix D: Requesting an USS Hip Scan
Step 1 – (Once entering patient EPR) Select Results Request on the Right side of the screen in the green buttons
Step 2 – Select Place Request (in box on left)
Step 3 – This will be the screen that appears after you press ‘Place Request'
Step 4 – In ‘Power Search' type US, and it should bring up the options
Step 5 – Once you select your USS Request, enter all the relevant details (ones with bold blue writing)
If the consultant is wrong, please follow the next step following clicking ‘…' box.
Step 5 continued.. Search for consultant, tick the box next to correct one and press + add then ‘OK'
Step 5 continued… Then make sure the consultant you added is ticked, and untick the incorrect one then ‘->Next'
Step 6 – Fill in all relevant information, highlighted in blue and press ‘Finish'
Step 7 – This will be the screen you will see when the request has been added
